Updated `tox` config to enable them, was easier than I thought. Hoping everything works.
Retest this please :)
LTGM, and thanks for adding the tests toos.

I just thought of a big downside to this: likely the local name will be used in the side input (state) protocol (and in particular the cache). Not allowing multiple names would mean the SDK would have to keep track of which ones actually represent the same collection. 

(As an aside, it seems edits are easier before we have code using them...)

retest this please

jenkins failed again, but retrieving the travis log (https://s3.amazonaws.com/archive.travis-ci.org/jobs/205968196/log.txt) is timing out when I try to access it, so not sure on cause.
retest this please

I don't understand what you mean by "not allowing multiple names". If a collection is side input twice, it will appears under two different names in the generic graph inputs and also under the same different names in the side inputs map. In general, the two specs in the side input map will be different and cached separately by the SDK harness post-`ViewFn`.

If you are suggesting adding a pre-`ViewFn` cache, and a desire to share whenever it has the same (PCollection, materialization) key, that seems pretty easy to implement too.

Perhaps you can say more to make me more worried?
Tests are not getting triggered for some reason, @jasonkuster will be taking a look soon.

Yes, I was thinking a pre-ViewFn cache. It's a question of imposing the
implementation of deduplicating the cache on something other than the local
name on *each* SDK. That being said, it could be that this is an uncommon
(and easy to implement if need be) improvement, so still worth doing this
change (I'm leaning that way) but wanted to call this out.

On Tue, Feb 28, 2017 at 10:35 AM, Kenn Knowles <notifications@github.com>
wrote:

> I don't understand what you mean by "not allowing multiple names". If a
> collection is side input twice, it will appears under two different names
> in the generic graph inputs and also under the same different names in the
> side inputs map. In general, the two specs in the side input map will be
> different and cached separately by the SDK harness post-ViewFn.
>
> If you are suggesting adding a pre-ViewFn cache, and a desire to share
> whenever it has the same (PCollection, materialization) key, that seems
> pretty easy to implement too.
>
> Perhaps you can say more to make me more worried?

OK, LGTM to move forward since there are no regressions that are caught by testing. The timing on presubmit - 34 min - seems within reasonable bounds so I am OK to increase individual test timeouts for now if we need to. Worst case we just move all of `CreateStreamTest` to postcommit. Let's wait and see.

As far as blocking the release for it, or hyping it with this release, I don't think we should since the new functionality isn't protected by tests. But for getting early feedback, sure.

Refer to this link for build results (access rights to CI server needed): 
https://builds.apache.org/job/beam_PostCommit_Java_RunnableOnService_Apex/635/
--none--

OK, still not worried :-)

I envision the SDK focusing on post-`ViewFn` cache since then it will have constructed a language-appropriate data structure that could actually be potentially expensive - today it is dramatically the case. So assuming smart decisions there, a pre-`ViewFn` cache might not actually have much benefit except in just this rare case where the same PCollection is viewed two ways. I wouldn't characterize it as deduplication, since the two different accesses to the same PCollection could easily have different enough access patterns to violate caching assumptions.

Out of scope here is that the runner's worker will likely manage a pre-`ViewFn` protocol including caching that is tightly coupled with the runner's private implementation of the materialization and possibly much more complex.

And if this turns out to be a wrong view of the future, I really thing the adaptation code will be quite trivial, ~zero in the scheme of things. Seems worth it for the clarity, though I don't care strongly either way; just a smidge more than style.

Generally (at least as implemented in the DirectRunner) it should be impossible for the `StatefulDoFn` itself to receive late elements, because we insert a full `GroupByKey` with the input's allowed lateness prior to reaching the `StatefulDoFn`

https://github.com/apache/beam/blob/master/runners/direct-java/src/main/java/org/apache/beam/runners/direct/ParDoMultiOverrideFactory.java#L145

I believe there's also been an idea floating around that there should be an `@OnWindowExpiration` method for Stateful DoFns, which would immediately precede the GCing of this state.
R: @kennknowles

R: @kennknowles 
CC: @amitsela @tweise @aljoscha
retest this please
Run Dataflow RunnableOnService

I'm only for blocking the release because I know it basically awaits merging. I agree about not "hyping", I'd wait with this a bit. But this could be good for "bleeding edge" users to get involved.

@tgroh Always inserting a `GroupByKey` would introduce latencies because we have to wait for the watermark to trigger the window and we would also get the whole window contents as an `Iterable`. In the Flink Runner we can just process elements as they are arriving. What we do is essentially this:
```
DataStream in = ...
in
  .keyBy(new KeySelector()) // this determines what to use for partitioning, for Beam it would get the K from a KV<K, V>
  .flatMap(new MyFancyStatefulFlatMap(StatefulParDo))
  ...
```

each incoming value has the window attached to it so we know which state to access and we just keep on processing as they come until we reach GC horizon and clear the state.

I don't know what the `DataflowRunner` does but to exhibit the same behaviour we would indeed have to silently drop incoming values that belong to a late window, as @JingsongLi suggested in his implementation.

@kennknowles or @tgroh, could you shed some light on what the `DataflowRunner` roughly does here?

I have a different take on what the direct runner does - the GBK is an implementation detail, mostly to achieved "keyed" status, but indeed drops late data. It has a hacked triggering to not hold anything back. Dataflow is roughly analogous. I think this PR is useful and could see myself using it to replace some ad-hoc code in the Dataflow runner.
Thanks Eugene. I will merge when green.

'Using context: Jenkins: Maven clean install --none--

My main claim was more regarding the correctness of dropping late data - I believe that it is correct to do so. State is accessed by both key and window; when an element arrives in a (post-merge) window that is expired, it has no guarantee that any state associated with that window remains, and thus any output it emits has no guarantee of being correct. Dropping it seems like the correct thing to do when this occurs. The GBK in the DirectRunner is just one way of doing so.
